The sonic distractor doesn't make any sound. The motion detector is very insensitive. Honestly I didn't mess with the microphone thing. Why would you need a microphone attached to an earbud??? If it was wireless then sure great item, but it is not.

So disappointed. Bought this for my 5 year old sons birthday present. Opened the package and half of the items don't work. The belt is huge! On its tightest setting it almost fits me, my son has to wear it across his shoulder because it is WAY too big for a child. I would not buy this nor would I recommend buying it.
I bought this as a birthday gift for my son. He really loves it. However the belt is hard to figure out and some stuff didn't work. But he still likes it anyway and has enjoyed it since he opened it.

name: Paladone Batman 15oz Travel Mug - The Dark Night Commuter Coffee Cup

reviews.review_text: I loved this cute batman travel mug...until it broke for no reason! I have been very careful to hand wash this mug every time I use it, which has been maybe a dozen times. I get home and immediately go to clean my mug and the cover for the mouth opening falls apart! At first I thought maybe it just slipped and would just pop back in, but I look at the actual piece and it looks corroded and jagged...like somehow the coffee melted the piece and that's why it fell apart?! You can see in the photos that this clearing didn't snap off and it wasn't broken off...it literally looks melted and corroded....I can't believe a coffee mug was melted by hot coffee! Who makes a coffee mug with a mouth piece that can't handle hot coffee? I am so upset because I love this mug and spent a little extra to show off my nerdy side and now it's fallen apart after 6 months and very little use. Will not be buying from this company again :( I'm so upset that this mug didn't work out and really wish I hadn't wasted $20 on this!

Paladone has been on fire lately. Introducing several new Batman themed items this year alone, their new travel mug is a really great addition and a fantastic buy. I love the weight of it and the solid rubber outer sleeve does a stellar job keeping beverages at exactly the temperature you desire for long drives. Recently I drove 300 miles and every refill of coffee remained hot to very warm for well over an hour 1/2 each time. The raised design includes the Bat-symbol and a series of grips that are all made of the same soft rubber as the rest of the sleeve. They are not hard so your fingers will not feel funky when gripping this mug to sip. The slide opening provides amble space for your bev to flow and the airflow is good eliminating any liquid slow down due to minimal aeration. The top/lid screws into place and seals incredibly well with no dripping or spills. Cleaning is a breeze under hot, soapy water with a soft brush or dish mop. I would not recommend placing in a dishwasher due to the chance of moister seeping in between the sleeve and the metal cup. The sleeve fits very snugly, but I just wouldn't trust it in a machine. The Paladone Batman Travel Mug is perfectly priced for the quality and I highly recommend it for any Batman fan who has to have their morning cup o' java before even thinking about fighting crime for the day.
reviews.review_header: The Perfect Travel Mug For Your Batmobile!

reviews.review_text: Unless I just had the bad cup, this product is garbage. I was only able to use it once - barely. It leaked as soon as I tried drinking from it. I thought maybe i titled it too much. NOPE. I just couldn't drink out of it like any normal person would drink from their coffee mug. And not to mention, it is a pain to clean. The sleeve does not come off easily, so have fun with that. However, I wouldn't base my review on that. The fact that it would leak just made the product useless. Wouldn't recommend it. Cool look but not usable and annoying to clean.
reviews.review_header: Unless I just had the bad cup, this product is garbage

reviews.review_text: This cup looks great, and it really good quality, but the problem is that the base of the cup is too wide to fit in standard car cup holders. That was disappointing. So it's for at home use only, not travel.
I just love this Mug: no spills, keeps my tea warm almost the whole day... and is a Bat-Mug!!! So much epicness.
My fiance loves his coffee and his Dodge charger/bat mobile (the man is 64!!!!), and this mug does the job! He loves it, buying another for spare.
reviews.review_header: My fiance loves his coffee and his Dodge charger/bat mobile ...

reviews.review_text: I bought this coffee mug for my boyfriend and he loves it. He uses it every morning and is satisfied
Great sturdy quality! Have had it for a few months now and it's still in great condition. I've accidentally dropped it and it's survived. Made a great gift for my boyfriend.

name: Fisher-Price Imaginext DC Super Friends, Transforming Batcave

reviews.review_text: I purchased this for my son's 4th birthday. He LOVES it. I, however, find it to be a huge pain in the behind! There are lots of small pieces that he leaves everywhere, and the cat steals, and he always needs help with the 'elevator' in the back (it gets jammed and he can't get the Joker up through to the top! Oh no!)... that being said.... He will spend HOURS playing with this (and a smaller supplemental set I purchased as well) using his imagination and truly PLAYING. I'll take a few missing pieces and a cranky elevator any day :)
reviews.review_header: Hours of fun for my 4 year old

reviews.review_text: If you have a son (or even a daughter) between 3 and 8 you need to buy this. Its big enough that both my sons can play with together, but independently of each other without fighting. I bought this a few months ago and my sons have not gotten bored of it yet. The eyes light up, but don't make any noise. (no noise is a positive for me) I wished it had a few more characters included, but my kids have a bunch of other imaginext guys that they don't mind so much.
reviews.review_header: I bought this a few months ago and my sons have not gotten bored of it yet

reviews.review_text: Not impressed! We have been avid supporters of Imaginext-finding many of their toys to be intelligently designed and well built. But this silly thing is so top heavy that it's really hard to play with, always tipping over. And the "elevator in the back is just ridiculous-doesn't move up and Dow well, is hard to access even for little hands, and the mini-figures always get stuck in there. Not impressed, especially at the price point.
reviews.review_header: Top heavy and unstable. A disappointment.

reviews.review_text: My 5-year-old grandson has gotten hours and hours of imaginative play with this toy. At his birthday party, even adults oohed and aahed as the wings expanded, the eyes lit up and flashed, while hidden doors opened. Each figure comes with a little indentation in the foot to secure it to the platforms that swivel, go up and down, and open up. There's a great YouTube video that shows all the features:[...]
reviews.review_header: 5-year-old grandson has gotten hours of imaginative play with this impressive toy

reviews.review_text: My son just LOVES this! But of course the day it's delivered the price goes down $6 cheaper than when I bought it a week ago ☹️ Zero complaints about the product! I'm so glad I bought it on amazon and NOT at Barnes and noble where it costs $65. Totally worth the $45 I spent and I can now get rid of a bunch of other toys while he is distracted with this one.

This is a fantastic toy. It has moving parts, missiles, lots of detail and the eyes of the cave at the top light up when you open up the wings. The best part about this is it allows kids to use their imagination - there is not so many sounds or lights that that is all they focus on. It has a garage, a jail cell, and an elevator (manual). My boys love playing with all of their imaginext figures on this batcave.

I bought this for my son's 3rd birthday. He absolutely loves it! Plays for hours with it. He has an older brother who is 8 and they both play with it together. Such imagination!! The only draw back is if you have animals, that like to chew on little things, watch them. We also have a 4 month old puppy that tries to get the small parts that come with this set. I knew it would be a hit in my house because Batman is also Mommy's favorite too! When my son found out that if you pull out the bat wings, it expanded and the eyes lit up he was so excited! Plus the "hidden" jail at the bottom was a hit as well. A lot of things to keep him busy and imaginative.
reviews.review_header: Wonderful birthday gift for my 3 year old son!

reviews.review_text: We are huge fans of Imaginext and own several sets! Fisher Price is a trusted brand that offers both durability and imaginative play. The new bat cave is impressive - tall and it offers multiple play features. I thought it would topple over during play, but it hasn't yet. We also purchased the Penguin Sub and additional figures. The only reason for four stars versus five stars is because I prefer last years model of the batcave a bit better. Overall, excellent value and makes a great gift!

Batfans, listen up … Batman: Return of the Caped Crusaders is deliciously satisfying! The characters, music, dialogue and trademark fight scenes are all here. Right from the opening credits, which cleverly intertwine the old 66 Batman television show with historic Batman comic book covers, one can immediately tell this animated film will not disappoint. The movie at its core is brilliant, using witty dialog and spectacular animation to entertain the viewer from start to finish. There are tons of Easter Eggs throughout that will satisfy the appetite of longtime fans. The Batcave’s decor is a great mix of Batman comics through the years and the tv show for which the film is based on. All items are woven together quite nicely. The story itself is not complex, but the manor it’s presented extremely creative. The voice acting is a nice mix of the classic actors themselves (which include Adam West, Burt Ward and Julie Newmar) along with others, which do a great job with the iconic characters. The true shining moment of this movie is the animation itself, which is pure eye candy! I’m amazed how incredible the lighting and colors burst on my HD screen. Why can’t all DC Animated films be this engaging? I highly recommend Batman: Return of the Caped Crusaders! FINAL GRADE = A

I caught the theatrical screening of this today and loved it! Fans of the classic Batman TV show will be delighted that all the classic gags and moments are faithfully included. Climbing a wall? Check. Onomatopoeias? Check. Absurd scenarios and puns? You know it! That said, this movie has its own story to tell. If they just reproduced the TV show beat for beat, it would probably still be pretty good, but as the film progresses it transforms into something really meaningful that uses the original show as a springboard for its own important message. I can't really go into the specifics of what makes this story so special without spoiling the greatest parts, but this is a smart, even introspective film made real passion. Animation-wise, this is a beautiful movie. I was worried how a straight-to-disc movie would look on the big screen, but I think this honestly could have been a regular theatrical release— the images are bold, beautiful and deserve to be seen on the largest screen possible. The likenesses of the classic actors have been captured brilliantly, the animation is smooth, and the artstyle is gorgeous. Gotham city manages to look like the Gotham of the classic TV show, but has that art-deco look DC's animated productions are known for. That the movie is animated also allows the story to do wonderful, insane things that are far beyond what the budget or special effects of the show could do in live action, but still feel true to the kind of things that would happen if the original production had the resources. Finally, the voice actors. Everyone is great! You can definitely hear the age in Adam West and Julie Newmar's voice (Burt Ward sounds the same as ever!), but everyone brings energy and heart to the table. The deadpan delivery of absurd dialogue that made the original so endearing is fully intact and makes for some excellent jokes. The non-returning cast do a great job imitating the original actors, and Wally Wingert in paticular is dead-on as the Riddler. Overall, this is a smart, beautiful, fun movie that will remind you of why we love classic Batman so much. This is a way more entertaining and engaging film than either of Batman's live action efforts this year. I've been rough on DC this year, but they really knocked this one out of the park.
reviews.review_header: Best Batman Movie of the year!

reviews.review_text: Batman and Robin defeat the Joker, Penguin, Riddler, and Catwoman in campy, cheesy farfetched plot packed full of alliterations, deus ex machina jams, classic fight scenes, weapon gags, and bat-labels for the bat-computer, bat-sprays, and bat-boosters. The color schemes and stage direction of the original series are faithfully recreated. The only things missing was the announcer saying at the end of the show, "Tune in next week. Same bat-time, same bat-channel."
reviews.review_header: The only things missing was the announcer saying at the end of the show, "Tune in next week. Same bat-time, same bat-channel."

reviews.review_text: Wow, DC did something right! All the elements you'd want in a new 1966 Batman are here except for the full theme song. The writers channeled Lorenzo Semple Jr. perfectly. The voice acting was great. The 3 returning stars know the roles inside and out by now, and the voices and mannerisms were spot-on for the newcomers, with the exception of the Penguin. To be fair, Burgess Meredith's voice seems like it would be the hardest to emulate, and I think the VA who did the Penguin did a good but not great job at the start of the film. Towards the end of the movie he seemed to get better at it, and if you watch the special features, he completely nails it when he does his Penguin voice in an interview. If Pengy returns in another one of these films I think he'd sound just like Burgess Meredith next time around. I was very impressed at how much the Joker sounded like Cesar Romero, and even more impressed by how well Wally Wingert captured Frank Gorshin's voice and mannerisms. There was only one thing I really didn't like about the movie, and that was the Joker's fart gag. There's no way Cesar Romero would have let his Joker do that, he had way too much class. I hope that the writers resist the urge to throw in gags like that in future installments. Two nit-picks I have are the lack of a white mustache on the Joker, and the Tyrannosaurus Rex statue in the Batcave. I don't mind that they added a T-Rex to the Batcave per se, but I wish they had used a more period-appropriate version. The '60s view of a T-Rex would have stood upright; it wasn't until the late 1980s that the modern view of T-Rex came about, with its spine parallel to the ground. Anyway, I hope to see more of these, and would love it if it became a regular TV series.

name: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice Mad Max: Fury Road, San Andreas 4K Ultra HD

reviews.review_text: The extended cut version is a far superior movie over the theatrical version we all saw in the theaters. THIS one makes more sense and the story line flows much better. Excellent special features!
reviews.review_header: Better than the theatrical cut by far !

reviews.review_text: I remember seeing the theatrical release of Batman vs Superman and genuinely enjoying it despite its faults, but still feeling like something was missing. And when the negative reviews began pouring in, I felt more than a little guilty about my opinion that the film was an entertaining (if somber) motion picture. Soon thereafter I received word of an extended release and hoped that it would provide that little bit which I felt was missing from the version that I saw twice in theaters... It absolutely delivered. This version provides that little element of heart that was unfairly cut out of the cinematic release, appropriately provided by the character with the biggest heart of them all: Superman. From calling up his mother in the middle of the night to seek guidance and emotional support, to going against his boss's instructions to shed light upon the people who are being hurt by Batman's vigilantism, and consistently helping others in spite of being distrusted and rejected by an unappreciative world who sees him only as a loose cannon (Anti-MoS fanboys, anybody?), this Superman provides the most human element of the story in this, THE definitive version of Batman vs Superman. In fact I find it very hard to regard him as the dark and violent sadist that the detractors of these DC movies see him as, considering that he does pretty much nothing to warrant such a label... that honor goes to Ben Affleck's dark, twisted, and unforgiving portrayal of Batman. Speaking of, Batman is undoubtedly the single biggest reason to see this movie. After three solid films by Christopher Nolan which depicted a semi-dark but overall heroic (and dare I say, unintimidating) version of the dark knight, Zack Snyder's take on the caped crusader gives us an interesting portrayal the likes of which we've never really seen before, borrowing heavily from Frank Miller's seminal graphic novel The Dark Knight Returns. This Batman is an old and broken man, bitterly stubborn and Hell-bent on bringing down Superman, no matter what the cost. And I DO mean that in the most drastic of terms, for it seems that Batman's 20-year reign of terror has left him indifferent to the lives of criminals; at one point in the film during an exciting chase scene, for instance, we see the Batmobile snag a car holding some thugs and use it to dispatch a second car, no doubt killing virtually everyone inside of both vehicles in the process. But unlike in Tim Burton's duology, Christopher Nolan's films, and even Joel Schumacher's "Batman Forever" (wherein we see Batman remorselessly kill three thugs, a buttload of ninjas, The Joker, The Penguin, Two-Face (twice), Ra's Al Ghul, AND Talia Al Ghul), this time around we're given a look at Bruce's psychology as well as some clues to give us an idea of why this version of Batman is so cruel and harsh towards criminals. It's... honestly surprising that people give this film such a hard time about Batman's "killing spree" when this is absolutely NOT breaking any new ground with him. But hey, could be worse; he could be making out with Black Canary while some criminals burn to death nearby. *Cough*(All-Star Batman)*Cough* Now that I've covered both of the main stars, I'd like to briefly cover the titular fight which everyone paid to see. Put simply, it's a satisfyingly brutal bout between two titans of the genre that have never shared the screen before. Batman's mechanical armor from The Dark Knight Returns is beautifully recreated in live action, and I'm glad to say that it was largely a practical effect rather than a CGI costume (ala Iron Man) and as a result, it feels appropriately bulky, intimidating, and powerful. I WAS somewhat disappointed that it didn't grant Batman any enhanced strength, merely serving instead as a means by which Batman may take the brunt of Superman's strength without harm, but at the very least it serves its purpose very well. Both characters give it their all, and without spoiling how the fight actually ends it stands as the emotional peak of the movie. (Yes, fanboys, I liked how the fight ended... for a detailed analysis as to why, and with no restraint on spoilers, I refer you to CinemaWins' spectacular video "Everything Great About Batman Vs Superman") This summarizes my major plus-points about the overall experience. I do, however, take issue with the climax of the film. That is not to say that it doesn't deliver exactly what it sets out to; it IS explosive and action-packed, with appropriately epic visuals and a suitably intimidating and powerful villain, but honestly after the spectacular fight between Batman and Superman (which I was far more invested in) the final battle simply bored me. It DOES end on a surprising note, however, which I shan't spoil here (although anybody who's familiar with the source material this film was based on might be able to wager a reasonable guess). Plus we finally got to see Wonder Woman in action for the first time ever in a major big-screen motion picture, so there's also that plus. Believe it or not, I'm one of those few people who is just fine with Jesse Eisenberg's Lex Luthor; I mean he's not the calm and collected mastermind we saw in the Superman and Justice League animated series, but I liked him well enough. At the very least his plan was deeply complicated, he seemed to have contingencies for just about everything, AND he has some of the best lines in the film. So it's a mixed bag; either you love him or you hate him. Overall I give this movie a 4 out of 5. Too many people have forgotten just how lucky we are to even have this thing; 10 years ago it would never have even been conceivable, yet now because of Marvel's super happy fun time superhero movies (which I should mention I am also quite fond of) we've become spoiled and ungrateful for what we have. This film attempts to be different than Marvel's straightforward super-fare by offering a thought-provoking analysis of Superman and what it would really be like to have such a powerful being in our modern world of cynicism and distrust, and the fans took one look at it and went "why can't it be all fun and happy like Marvel's doing??" and refused to appreciate the movie's good points, of which there are many. To me, this film stands not only as an outstanding Batman/Superman movie as well as a monolith of just how far we've come in the medium of superhero movies as a whole. Thank you, Zack Snyder, for this monumental achievement. I'm proud to own your imperfect masterpiece here on Amazon.
reviews.review_header: Playing the Devil's Advocate: This Film Is Spectacular

reviews.review_text: As a father of two 'tweens, I have seen my share of superhero movies, and I can't stand most superhero movies for precisely the issue this movie deals with ... the 'judge, jury, executioner' nature of having superpowers. Imagine I traveled to a planet where the inhabitants were about the weight and consistency of styrofoam peanuts, and I spent my time kicking them to and fro for my own reasons. Would that make me virtuous, would it make me super? And even if I did it with the best of intentions, wouldn't they have every reason to fear me? And how could I assure them, how could I assure myself I would be the one person in history immune to the absolute corruption of absolute power? It is problematic, and I appreciate this movie dealing with the problematic nature of the "superhero" issue. Spoiler alert: I disagree with those who criticize the hard turn the movie takes when Batman and Superman resolve their difference seemingly over their mothers' shared name. For one, Batman relents when he understands Superman's motivation is to protect his mother --- the shared name is merely a device to catch his attention. For obvious back-story reasons, Batman is highly motivated by the possibility that Superman could fail to protect his mother, and that's the *substantive* reason he decides to help him rather than fight him. I do think the conflict could still be carried forward with an only uneasy truce between Batman and Superman. That would make for a better story, both dramatically and, in my opinion, philosophically. That quibble aside, this movie, in contrast to almost every superhero movie, has well-written, natural-sounding dialog, fewer "cinema sins", almost-perfect casting, compelling acting, and truly beautiful imagery that is a breed apart from the overly-filtered awkward CGI of so many movies like this. I'm deeply surprised that it has received such poor reviews when other movies that I've found almost unwatchable have received near-universal praise.
reviews.review_header: Deals with the most important "superhero" issue, in my opinion

reviews.review_text: This version of the film is an immense improvement in my opinion, so much so that I can say with all honesty I'll never watch the theatrical version ever again. Nearly every additional scene gives the film the clarity, characterization, and emotional resonance that was lacking before. This pushed what was a fair/good assessment of the film from me previously into the very good/great direction. Haters will likely still hate it, but I know I'm more than satisfied now with this ultimate cut. Update: After watching Wonder Woman recently, I wanted to go back and watch this film again to see any new revelations that could be grasped. Let's just say that the look of familiar despair on Diana's face at the end of the climatic battle with Doomsday took on a whole new weight after her film showed us her experiences with loss. The BvS ending was even more of a gut punch on this viewing and I found myself getting emotional just as I did during Wonder Woman. Try looking at this film with fresh eyes and perhaps you'll find the beauty therein.

name: Batman Bat Folding Dual Twin Double Blade Spring Assisted 5 Colors Pocket Knife Tactical Belt Clip Black Yellow Silver Blue Red Knives

reviews.review_text: This is a pretty awesome looking little knife. The bat shaping contours fit nicely in my hand (I don't have a large hand/grip). The build is solid and the blades are reasonably sharp and strong. Its not a "practical" pocket knife as it's thick, but The blades flip out easily and lock solidly.
reviews.review_header: This is a pretty awesome looking little knife

reviews.review_text: I read all the reviews, and saw a couple saying that theirs came really loose, and they weren't able to tighten in. I figured, screw it, it's only 10 bucks, and it's not like I'm buying it to really use it, it's more a decoration, so I took the risk. I opened it up, and it was perfect. No dings or tool marks, both blades are sturdy and open smoothly. It's also surprisingly comfortable to hold, considering how chunky the hilt is. Perfect for any batman fan, or anyone who like off stuff. And again...it was ten dollars, definitely worth it.
Awesomeness. Exceptional quality esp at this price point! Fits the contours of the hand very well, feels solid and the spring action is very quick. An all around steal. 5 Stars.
reviews.review_header: Awesomeness. Exceptional quality esp at this price point! ...

reviews.review_text: This is a neat looking knife, and as advertised. That being said, it is the most impractical knife I own. The dual blades make this just silly, unless you are in some sort of combat and even then it's questionable. As a utility knife or pocket knife, it's just not practical. The spring assist is almost unwelcome considering there is little safe space to place your fingers when opening. Neat to look at. Impulse buy that I will keep, but not a practical.

It's a cute little knife and was purchased as a gift. The blades easily open up. I'm giving it four stars because when I received it, it had a scratch on it but I was in a time crunch and didn't​ have time to exchange it. I wish the distributors would have quality control before sending out items.
reviews.review_header: Great knife, just wish it didn't come scratched

reviews.review_text: My son loves the knife, but 3 stars because we ordered red and received black. The box even identified it as red so we opened it. He loves it and didn’t want to have to give it up to return it, but was disappointed we received the wrong color.
THIS KNIFE IS AWESOME!!!! Being a family of superhero fans I was thrilled to get this for my Dad to add to his collection. It's a knife, so this is a given, but man is it sharp!!!
Awesome knives! I bought 2. One for me and one for my brother for Christmas. I 💓 mine and so has everyone I've showed it too.

reviews.review_text: It’s cute decent size thought it would be a bit bigger for the price but not to small or too big quality of the look n feel is good too bought this for my nephew he loves LEGO Batman
I bought this for a boy’s 7th birthday party. He loved it. The seams were sturdy. No loose threads. I was happy with it.

I love this Batman plush! It’s exactly what we were looking for and I can’t wait until my son sees it on Christmas morning! Thank you for a great product and speedy shipping.

I thought this movie was fantastic! I rented, and now I will buy it. I've watched it more than 5 times during my rental period and can't seem to get enough of the "Let's Get Nut's" Batman song in the beginning of the movie. As for whether or not it's for kids, I'll leave these comments as this is coming from a 37 year old: I didn't think it was any more or less violent than Despicable Me or Monsters University. However, my young ones didn't understand many references made in the movie despite finding it enjoyable. Specifically, there are many references (hilarious ones or hilariously spun) that are either before many 10 year old's time, are from movies that were not for children, or are not part of US pop culture. For example, "You wanna get nuts?! Let's get nuts!" is from the 1989 Batman movie (I was 9 when that movie came out...and yes I watched it and didn't understand it until I watched it again as an adult). The Eye of Sauron is from Lord of the Rings, a PG-13 movie. Or the Daleks from Dr. Who (NIIIIIICE!!), which are awesome but part of British pop culture. ELIMINATE! ELIMINATE! ELIMINATE! ...yes, I am a closet Whovian. I'm sure the adults appreciate the homage to the 1960's Batman (rest in peace Adam West) as represented by Alfred's batsuit and the underlying theme song. Also the "Pow!" and other visual fight sounds were enjoyable. The humor was on point! I loved the sarcasm and indirectly making fun of...Batman. "'Puter! Overcompensate!" "What is the password?" "Ironman sucks!" I'm not always into these types of movies, but I thought it was honestly brilliant. Brilliantly written and just a bowl of laughs!
reviews.review_header: I've Watched This Movie 5 Times During The 36 Hour Rental!!

reviews.review_text: If you are a fan of the ridiculous, you will LOVE this movie. The comedy is silly, goofy and light-hearted. Will Armett nails it as Batman. The whole cast nails it! I loved this movie so much that I turned my digital rental into a purchase. And the song and dance number at the end? Laugh out loud!

Lego Batman totally made the first Lego Movie. This one is even better. It's hilarious. I'm 42 and I thoroughly enjoyed watching this with my 12 year old. The movie has a good message too. I love all the bad guy cameos in it also. Where else can you see Voldemort, Sauron, Joker and Batman in the same movie?

Where do I begin? The epic password to the Batcave? The phenomenal shout-outs to past Batmans? Everything is awesome about this movie! It actually confronts the fact that the character of Batman is a standoffish jerk--and forces him to do something about that. Ralph Fiennes made a wonderful Alfred, Rosario Dawson was everything I hoped for in Barbara Gordon--the writing is just great and I love so much about it. As pretty much a lifetime Batfan, this was a hugely satisfying film.

This is a great movie. I love and and all 3 kids actually sit down and watch it whenever we put it on. If you have little boys do not rent this one, buy it! It is very good and really cool they bring in some different characters like Sauron and Voldemort and King Kong! I like the message it sends- its like a family is more important than anything else message and work together and you can make the world a better place message. But still plenty of action and bad guys to go around but it makes the kids play with their legos a bunch every time they watch it- WHICH IS GREAT, THEY ARE SUCH AN EDUCATIONAL TOY AND WE HAVE TONS. Sparks creativity and Good vibes and great job on this movie.

This movie was cute, fun, funny in a laugh out loud kinda way and all the characters "actors" did a great job using their voices to their utmost potential in this film. I loved the last Lego movie that had Batman with the same actor voicing him. However, this movie was even more funny than that one was. There are jokes in the movie that only adults will get but nothing crude so it is suitable for the whole family. It left me with a big smile on my face and that is what I want in the summer, to be lazy and watch silly & funny movies. This one did all of that and more by teaching a few life lessons for Kids or Adults. Good job to Will Arnett as "Batman" and Michael Cera as "Robin", lol.
reviews.review_header: The Lego Batman Movie was just so very funny ;)

reviews.review_text: I didn't care for The Lego Movie all that much due to an almost 'Family Guy' barrage of references which seemed just for references sake. However, Batman gets it right. Only during a couple fight scenes was there too much going on ask at once. The story, the action, and the humor were totally on point for a great Batman flick. A must watch

reviews.review_text: Not safe for work/kids. As the not rated cover kinda gives you a hint towards. Adult themed Harley Quinn movie that includes Batman and Nightwig... oh I mean wing. 10/10 will watch again. Kinda like suicide squad-ish but replace Everyone except Harley with Batman and nightwing vs Poison Ivy with Jack. Pros: It's funny. Animated well, though a couple of frames are skipped. Not noticeable if just playing it like you should. Entertaining Unexpected solutions Cons: The community who seem to own the idea of what Batman and Nightwing have to be. The ending...? Though in all fairness it did fit with the movie. (soft con)
reviews.review_header: Kinda like suicide squad-ish but replace Everyone except Harley with Batman ...

reviews.review_text: I just wanted to add my voice to the others that this is not for young kids, at all. We have a restaurant like Hooters, but for girls scantily dressed as female superheroes and villains and some of the groping you might expect at a place like that, a long shot of Harley bending over in her underwear, a heavily implied sexual encounter, use of the S word and d-bag, a joke about calling a guy "when I run out a batteries," Harley flipping the bird, Harley vigorously shaking her breasts... That's the first 30 minutes. None of that bothers me in the slightest because I'm a 30 year old man but it felt worth mentioning for the sake of parents, since this is in a similar style to other more kid friendly Batman series'. Other than that, it's definitely not the best, not the worst. Harleys voice is pretty grating. I mean, it always is, but it seems more noticeable since it's not Tara Strong or Arleen Sorkin, whose particular pitch many of us have gotten used to. I don't have much else to say, it's a pretty standard adventure, I probably wouldn't watch it a second time.
reviews.review_header: Heed the PG-13 rating, it earns it.

reviews.review_text: Oh my. So very much not for kids. It's rated PG-13, and it earns every bit of it. At first I was thrilled to see the old Batman: The Animated Series style. That show had some dark themes but there were certain lines never crossed. That line was leaped over in this outing. I was glad to hear Conroy & Lester back as Batman & Robin/Nightwing. I missed Arlene Sorkin as Harley. Melissa Rauch does a decent job, but her Harley is SO much more abrasive than Sorkin's. And to be honest, that kind of sums up this whole movie. It has moments of sweetness, and belly-laugh comedy. It also has odd musical sequences and some Easter Eggs for fans of old BTAS. But it has some really crude humor. And several times I thought "I cannot believe they just did that." This isn't just the kind of show that I'd have to watch with my kids. Frankly, I wouldn't feel comfortable letting my kids watch it. In fact, I turned it off when they came in the room. I never had to do that with BTAS. That said, I look forward to discussing it with other middle aged nerds who were BTAS fans.
reviews.review_header: NOT FOR KIDS AT ALL ! Batman The Animated Series by way of Porky's.

reviews.review_text: The goon club was the best part - although the singing is cringeworthy. A lot of henchmen from the animated series are there, and remember how Captain Clown is a robot? Notice his dance partner? She's the robot daughter from that one episode where the machines are trying to replace people. Nice attention to detail. Not a great movie by any stretch, and did anyone notice how Harley had her life somewhat together, it was Nightwing that accosted her? She should've just pressed charges and continued on with her waitress career.
reviews.review_header: Fans of the animated series might enjoy seeing some things, and really hate others

reviews.review_text: My least favorite Batman animated movie , did not like the new voice of Harley Quinn at all or the way Nightwing was handled

It's a comedy first, a Batman movie second. The way I would describe this whacked out movie is that it is a Batman tale, if the events of that tale were recounted by Harley. Despite how completely asinine it is, I liked the movie, but I can see hardcore Batman/DCU fans not liking this because of how out there and unbatman it feels.
reviews.review_header: What the actual heck is this movie even?

reviews.review_text: I've been a Batman my entire life. I loved the animated series. This was a huge disappointment on every level. The story is campy (actually did the fight sound effect words in one scene), Batman who always has a plan seemed clueless, Harly Quinn was trying too much to be a good guy, and what humor there was childish. The entire story should be an embarrassment to a team that in the past produced some of the best superhero animation anywhere.

The first 25 minutes... absolutely hilarious. And completely worth watching. I thought I was going to be in for a real treat and a 5 star rating. After that, it goes down hill really fast. Fart jokes, ridiculous Batman decisions, and just plain poor writing. One of the worst parts was a small speech by Harley talking about how complicated it is to write "their or they're" depending on is usage... Considering Harley Quinn has a PHD in psychology, I found it more than a little insulting to the character. She's crazy... not stupid. I wish I stopped watching after the first 25 minutes. But those 25 minutes were amazing, and the only reason this got 3 stars.
reviews.review_header: Harley is supposed to be crazy... not stupid.

name: DC Batman 2-Slice Toaster

reviews.review_text: THE GOOD I had to replace my toaster, after all toaster's do not last forever. I decided since it was time to shop for a new toaster that I would downgrade from my large 4-slice toaster to a quaint 2-slice toaster to gain some counter space. I saw this little baby on Amazon and it caught my eye, plus the price was awesome, under $16. The color and graphics are just as bright and cheery in "person" as it looks in this picture. A nice rich red with Mickey looking at toward the slice slots, keeping an eye on your food for you. The settings are pretty accurate as far as how dark or light you prefer your toast. The coolest part is that it leaves a Mickey Mouse head-shaped outline on one side of your toast. Since it totally toasts one side, it doesn't taste like untoasted bread in those areas on the other side. The slots are large enough for bigger items like bagels, which makes it useful for all types of breakfast foods and snacks. At first, I was going to list this as a negative, but luckily I was wrong. My old toaster had a CANCEL button, which worked most of the time. This Mickey Toaster does not. Instead, you turn the setting knob all the way to the left, and this cancels your toasting. So far it works every single time I've tried it. It seems that this toaster, although I have to wait to toast my bread items when I have more than two to toast, it toasts much quicker than my earlier model. I love that it toasts so quickly, there's nothing worse than waiting for toast. THE BAD One thing that I don't like is that the toaster almost feels like a toy. Despite the fact that it toasts so well, it is very light and therefor a bit cheap-feeling. But having said this, I feel like this is something that I'd get used to kind of quickly. Overall - I love this toaster. Guests comment on its good looks. If they receive toast, they gush over the Mickey Head shape. I recommend this to fans of Disney and toasted bread everywhere.

This toaster was awesome. It was a Christmas gift from my wife. We set it up shortly after Christmas. We both used it 2-3 times per week since purchasing it. This past weekend it stopped functioning properly. When you press the toast down into the toaster (where you'd expect it to click), it no longer clicks and locks. It just pops up. Will it make toast? Sure, if you hold the lever down the entire time. Pretty useless now. I'm very dissatisfied. This product should last more than 3 months.
reviews.review_header: Stopped working after 3 months of limited usage

reviews.review_text: I used this for the first time this morning. It started smoking up alot so I turned it straight off. I read the instructions and it said something along the lines of 'it might have alot of smoke and an odor to begin with but it will disappear the more you use it'. So I'm like oh ok it's normal so I turned it back on and after not even 5 seconds it was on fire! This toaster has gone straight in the bin. I've read other reviews and no one else has said this? Don't know what was wrong with mine?

Its absolutely wonderful for the price and the kids love it. It does stink from time to time so you'll need to clean it more often than others, but I've had it a while now and it still works pretty good. My only other complaint is the temperature doesn't work right. What I mean by that is at the lowest setting you have to push it down twice for regular toast, you can't turn it up even one or it gets burnt. And with store baked bread, as in the kind you by uncut loafs of like the french bread, you can only push it down once and then have to let it sit in there. Also, the mickey label doesn't always show, unless its a bit crispy. Now don't get me wrong, I love this toaster, its absolutely wonderful for the price and I love the design.

Oh My! Mickey arrived and no bread in the house! I put it (the toaster) through a few dry runs without toast to off-load any new product smell. Frankly it just smelled like something toasting! It made me crave toast! But it was 11 PM and I wasn't going to go out for bread! Some people complain it is toy like...well, what do you expect? Have you ever been to Disney territory? Toy-like stuff can still work pretty well. It is inexpensive, cute, and I think will do it's job. For some reason I have not owned a toaster for over a decade. (I just didn't eat toast.) Well, now I am into it. I also think the slots are plenty wide for bagels. I like the cool-touch feature. It does not get super hot to touch. This thing is sooooo cute...matches the red accents in my kitchen. As well, I am not an early bird person and bought Mickey to help me out and I think it is a good plan. Buy this for everyone for Christmas! Especially morning grumps like me :)

Super cute! I love that it puts a image of Mickey mouse on the toast. It has several levels of darkness to pick from. We like stuff lightly toasted and it still puts an image on the toast or bagel. The image is harder to see with the wheat bread that we eat, but it is still visible....we tried it on white to see what it looks like, it works best on white bread. But it is still an excellent toaster. No matter what type of bread or bagel goes in there, it toasts perfectly.
It is much lighter than expected, meaning it doesn't feel very sturdy. The "toast marks" on the bread don't really look like Mickey at all. I've only had it about a week. It seems to work well.

I read a lot of reviews and I was afraid of the toaster burn or melt, that's all. I don't use every day and yes some 2 times a week. I bought but haven't bothered much by the fact that I don't use much. So here is what I have to say: For the first time I used the smell of burned plastic appeared. You can smell plastic burning and that’s not cool. Unfortunately the material looks pretty cheap and it’s cheap. It’s very light material and burn the bread really fast too. So start using the number 2. Number 3 burned my toast. But like I said, I leaned how to use, I barely use and I love Mickey Mouse. So I’m happy with my purchase. Don’t recommend for families or for who likes a GOOD MADE TOAST!

by a twist of an atypically benevolent Fate, Adam West lived just long enough to send his best and most beloved role out in a certain amount of style. his portrayal was as ethical yet winsome as ever, and despite being noticeably thinned by age, his voice had lost none of it's heroic authority. also along for the ride are Burt "Robin" Ward and Julie "Catwoman" Newman, both of whom simimarly retain the thrust that made their characters resonate. based upon a revivalist comic-book series, the goal here was clearly to find a middle-ground between the whimsy of West's tv series and the grittier version(s) of more recent years. for the most part they did an impressive job. it has both the grandeur of Batman's more recent cartoons and the freewheeling sense of humor of West's heyday. for instance, at one point Batman is clonked on the head and briefly sees triple, and the two addition Catwomen are caricatures of fellow former Catwomen Lee Meriwether and Eartha Kitt. or take the legal precedent cited of "Dozier Vs. Semple." obviously this refers to William Dozier, producer/narrator of the original series, and Lorenzo Semple Jr., author of many episodes. once or twice, it might even be too clever for it's own good. Robin's exclamation of "Holy Faster Pussycat! Kill! Kill!" is plenty amusing in context, but i fear it will leave the overanalysts scratching their heads. after all, how could that paragon of wholesome, The Boy Wonder, possibly know about Russ Meyer movies? some key actors, alas, were shortsighted enough to die before the project was even envisioned, leaving us to settle for imitators. not that they do at all poorly: the voices behind The Joker and The Riddler do an admirable job of replicating the essences of Caesar Romero and Frank Gorshin, but whoever plays The Penguin falls so laughably short of Burgess Meredith, one wonders if he's actually even trying. i've said before and i'm prepared to say again that The Penguin is easily the corniest nemesis i've ever seen Batman (or any other superhero) come up against...unless he's in the form of Burgess Meredith. God knows how Meredith managed to transcend the limited character he had to work with, but somehow he did, making all Penguins to come (not least of which Danny DeVito) that much harder to take seriously. add the fact that character acts as part of a gang rather than doing anything on his own account, and it becomes all too unmissable: The Penguin is present strictly for the Marquee value, less because he actually contributes something than because he was expected. the rest of the cast does a pretty good job. Aunt Harriett sounds just like Madge Blake, although curiously isn't drawn to look much like her. and Alfred remains the loyal, lovable right-hand man of old. which is all the more impressive when one learns he's played by, of all people, Steven Weber from Wings. they didn't manage to rekindle all the classic tropes, i'm afraid. there are exotic death traps but obviously no cliffhangers. there are no special guest cameos in the window when they scale a building. nor is there any sign of Batgirl. (presumable because Yvonne Craig had shuffled her own mortal coil not long before.) but fortunately there's only one omission for which the whole actually suffers: no glib narrator to take over for producer Bill Dozier. Return Of The Caped Crusaders, title notwithstanding, effectively picks up where we left off. the plot concerns a concoction of Catwoman's - which she terms "Batnip" - designed to relieve our hero of any conscience or ethics. it turns out to work more gradually than she was counting on, but it does ultimately manage to make a monster out of him. things officially get really hairy when he uses the story's resident McGuffin, the "Replication Ray," to reproduce corrupted Batmans (Batmen?) by the seemingly hundreds. then comes Batman Vs. Two-Face, which, in the classic "special guest villain" mode, features William Shatner in the antagonist role. he's even drawn to not-so-subtly resemble Captain Kirk. this could be a case of wish fulfillment, because a semi-legendary unproduced episode would've featured Harvey Dent and his Mr. Hyde in the '60s. the "treatment" for said episode was by noted science-fiction author Harlan Ellison, who, perhaps coincidentally, also wrote Shatner's favorite Star Trek exploit, "The City On The Edge Of Forever." one of the coolest angles here is a promise followed up on. a prison break scene from Return features glimpses of many of the villains from the series, but doesn't really do anything with them. the Two-Face movie actually begins to work them into the foreground, giving underused foes King Tut and Bookworm brief but juicy role in the central action. one can only surmise what further installments would've had in mind for Egghead, Shame, Siren, and/or Mr. Freeze. one nifty in-joke concerns the lawyer who's identity Catwoman escapes prison by assuming, complete with a swapping of outfits. this hapless is soul is played the aforementioned Lee Meriwether, who stood in when Juile Newmar was unavailable for the Batman movie in 1966. perhaps most significantly, recent events allowed the credits to set one record straight. i've mentioned before how the "dark knight" version of Batman is little more than a plagiarism of The Shadow, but it turns out that was only the beginning of alleged creator Bob Kane's perfidy. it turns out that he wasn't really a writer so much as an artist, and was "helped" more than a little by one Bill Finger. it seems the man dressed as a bat was pretty much the extent of Kane's contribution. everything else - the dead parents backstory, most of the rogue's gallery, even the name "Batman" - are courtesy of Finger, but due to some contractual hocus-pocus, Kane got sole credit for decades. Kane was never likely to personally rectify the situation, given that he turned out to be a hammy limelight junkie, a' la Paris Hilton or Zsa Zsa Gabor. it was only around 2010 that efforts were taken on Finger's behalf to secure the credit he deserved, and while the campaign proved difficult and time consuming, it was successful in time for these films, and the tv show Gotham, to be able to officially sight Bill Finger's contribution. by an interesting historical footnote, the one piece of Batman for which Finger managed in his lifetime to claim official credit - "The Clock King's Crazy Crimes"/"The Clock King Gets Crowned" - is an Adam West episode. but i digress... it might feel incomplete, because it was meant to be a longer series. Adam West was taken from us before it could be taken any father. of course there's always the possibility that they'll recast the role, and who knows, maybe they'll find someone who can adequately replicate his essence. but then, maybe not. be that as it may, rest in peace, Adam. not Michael Keaton, not George Clooney, not even Christian Bale could even begin to take your place. if, in the words of Queen (and/or Highlander), there can be only one, it's you, Adam.

A great and sad year for Batman.......Us fans of the 60s Batman finally get the Dynamic Duo back with great new movies....only to lose the true West....the guys did a great job...everyone did....sad to see it end......I even liked how they showed West in the Lego Batman(very funny movie).....We will keep the Bat Signal on for ya Adam West........Thank you
reviews.review_header: A great and sad year for Batman

reviews.review_text: As a kid, I started watching the 1966 Batman TV show via reruns in the early 1970s. We didn't know the dark, brooding, violent Batman back then, only the over-the-top campy fun of what they now term "the Bright Knight". We loved that as kids. While I do enjoy more modern, darker interpretations, I feel there's a place in history for both, and I'm thrilled that we were given one last romp with the TV cast. This movie nails the look and feel of the live-action TV show in all its glorious silliness, right down to wall walking, and the headgear on the evil draining machine looking like cheezy prop recycling of 1960s salon hair dryers. The movie creators clearly know it is ridiculous and play it for additional laughs. Just look at some of the crazy signage in the background of the climactic struggle. An old fan can also appreciate some of the meta jokes, such as some things that happen with Lee Meriweather's character. Burt Ward was really on top of his voice role, sounding like a college student much of the time. But the real treasure was bringing Bill Shatner in for the Harvey Dent role. As soon as I heard it announced during production of the movie, I cheered. Shatner awesomely handled a dual role before in Star Trek's "Wolf In The Fold" episode, so I knew the character was in great hands, and he delivered as expected. I wistfully wish this had been a second live-action Batman movie back in the 1960s just to have Shatner act it. I'd also add that it was great of the writers to bring back two of my favorite 1960s villains to flesh out the full story. Again, I'd only wish this would have been the old live action to have Victor Buono and Roddy McDowell reprise their roles. There were actually several of the TV show villains cameoed throughout, some with minor speaking roles. The only thing I wrinkled my nose at was the inclusion of the Otto Preminger version of Mr. Freeze, the weakest of three actors who played the role on TV. I would have preferred either of the other actors, Eli Wallach or George Sanders, as the template for the animated cameo. Lastly, this film also marks the first (and sadly, only) appearance of two other prominent Batman villains in the 1960's canon. Look for them when the testing room first fills with villains. One of them is a cameo (with a bit more air time in the Blue Ray version) with a very distinctive accent, and the other fills a more substantial role. If you're one of the younger generation of viewers who don't seem to get the campy fun of the 1960s, don't bother watching. You'll only be miffed and rate it a 1-star (which it is not). But if you don't mind letting go of a host of dark-and-brooding pre-conceptions and are willing to embrace a lot of zany fun, then grab a bowl of popcorn and sit back with a friend for a great time.
reviews.review_header: Really pegs the look and feel of the 1966 Batman TV show

reviews.review_text: Normally I'd give this video 4 stars, but they added a really nice tribute to Adam West in the extras. This is pretty much his last work (not counting a couple of bits he had pre-recorded way in advance for last year's season of Family Guy). So it was bittersweet watching it. I have been a fan of the Adam West Batman series since the first episode was broadcast in 1966. Nice touch adding that other great 1960s TV icon, William Shatner, to the cast of this cartoon.
reviews.review_header: Two 1960s TV Icons on one disk.

reviews.review_text: Campy just like the original tv series. If you like the Adam West series you’ll like this, I didn’t .
Holy throwback, this was a fun movie! Rick Moranis did an excellent job bringing back the camp of the original series. If you liked the original series, you gotta watch this.

name: BlenderBottle Justice League Superhero Classic 28-Ounce Shaker Bottle, Batman

reviews.review_text: Cup is amazing in person. It looks just like the image and doesn't leak or anything when I use it. I love the colors and should anything happen to my cup I'll definitely it buy again.

This was exactly what I wanted. I browsed other shaker cup options and for the price of a plain one or one with a brand logo I didn't recognize I figured I might as well spend an extra dollar or two and go for this one. Cute, but completely functional. Lid stays tight while I mix my shake, blender ball gets the powder all mixed in, no annoying powdery chunks. Measure marks, easy to clean. All around lovely.

I like the Batman logo, obviously. The lid snaps closed tightly and hasn't ever leaked. The little carrying handle is nice. My protein does tend to clump though, so the little mixing ball isn't as effective as I'd like. Overall though, I've found it to be a good value.
reviews.review_header: Cool looking, does what it's supposed to.

reviews.review_text: I'm glad I ordered from Amazon rather than buying a Batman shaker bottle from Walmart. Why? This is the BlenderBottle brand! Any other brand of shaker bottle never seems to hold up as well. I'm always very pleased with the quality of these bottles, and this one is no exception.
reviews.review_header: The real deal. Great quality, as expected.

reviews.review_text: Very very satisfied with this bottle. Looks great, good quality, and I use it daily!
Love this bottle. It has yet to leak when I shake it up, and it's fairly easy to clean, though with all shakes it's hard to completely get the smell out. Best design!

Nothing special shaker bottle wise. Pretty much your standard bottle with your favorite super hero's logo. My girlfriend loves the shaker, it came pretty fast(probably varies by location) and I'd buy it again for her.
reviews.review_header: Pretty much your standard bottle with your favorite super hero's ...

reviews.review_text: Love this shaker. I love wonder woman so it was perfect. The lid closes nicely and it does what it’s suppose to do.

Seeing as how i never read the original comic, I watched the movie with a unbiased fresh perspective. I honestly enjoyed this movie a great deal. I am a huge fan of both Batman and Sherlock Holmes, so seeing the two world's collide was quite a treat. The characters were all likable, still keeping the base components of their original personalities intact but also fitting their different time period and circumstances well enough to evolve into their new roles. The voice acting and story were solid, and i enjoyed trying to deduce the story right along with the characters (why I love mysteries and detective stories). My biggest complaints probably fell on the animation. I was fine with the art resembling the old Batman Animated series I knew and love, but the backgrounds often felt cheap and the random bits of CG that were poorly integrated were eye catching and not in a good way. At least I loved the character designs. Seeing everyone in the Victorian garb was great and the fight scenes where nicely done and surprisingly graphic and violent which I think perfectly fit the movies mood and kept things moving at a nice exciting pace.
reviews.review_header: A dark gritty mystery where the Batman and Sherlock world's collide!

reviews.review_text: Batman Gotham by Gaslight is an animated movie based on the elseworlds story of the same name Gotham by Gaslight. Where Batman is taken to the late 19th century Gotham to fight one of history notorious killers Jack the Ripper. The Animated movie is not a direct adaptation of the comic, so the identity of Jack the Ripper has been completely redone from the comic as well as the overall stories. Gotham by Gaslight does an excellent job incorporating many of the Batman characters who weren’t in the original comic. They fit in well with the source material, especially the three Robins Dick, Jason, and Tim. With them being cleverly designed as these street beggars. On the opposite you have Catwoman, Selina Kyle who felt ham-fisted throughout the plot. Catwoman is the replacement of Julie Madison who was the original love interest in the comic. I understand the replacement as Catwoman is the more well-known love interest but the way they shoved her in at times that felt force and killed the pacing. Aside from that Catwoman is incorporated well to the plot. Voice Acting was well done Bruce Greenwood returns as Batman does a great job, Jennifer Carpenter played a great Catwoman. The film is not shy about showing blood as the Ripper scenes are straight out of a horror film earning it a rated R rating. The Animation is the biggest flaw of the movie that holds it back while I can praise the Art style for nailing the Steampunk Batman look especially at night. The animation leaves more to be desired awkward movements and bizarre transitions to 3D animation left me disappointed on how far DC has become lazy. The look and style are great as mentioned before it does nail down the comic book aesthetic but in motion not so much. At the end Batman Gotham by Gaslight was enjoyable. It did the Jack V. Batman better than the original comic. It incorporated most characters in an organic fashion. It brought a 19th century Batman and his Steampunk inspired tech. One of DC’s better Batman films not as great as the older ones but not as bad the newer ones. It’s a Steampunk Batman fighting Jack the Ripper! A must watch for fans of The Batman.
reviews.review_header: A dark and gritty Steampunk Batman

reviews.review_text: This is fantastic! As a fan of the original book I love that they just took the idea and did something very different with it. Honestly the original story wouldn't translate well, so this was a very smart move. I really like all the other Victorian takes on classic Batman characters, personal favorite would be the street tough Robins. Also I'm not sure if it's cause of Batman and Catwoman's recent romance and engagement in the comics but I really like seeing these two as a couple more and more in media. The animation is good, the voice acting is great and the action is awesome.
reviews.review_header: A fun and fresh take on a classic story

reviews.review_text: Like the movie adaptations of the 1940s, where the title and setting were all that you could count on being true to the original, this adaptation it true to the title and setting of the original graphic novel and not much else. That said, I like this story a little better. Here the outcome and the nemesis is less predictable than the graphic novel. In a way, this reminds me of Justice League Gods and Monsters where the creative team gave themselves the freedom to mix up the cast, the origins, and the outcomes. I have to admit to a little hypocrisy in that while I like the fact the creative team confounded expectations, Batman not being voiced by Kevin Conroy was a bit distracting. In short, if you have your heart set on seeing a slavishly faithful translation of the original graphic novel, you will be disappointed. But if, like the movie audiences of old, you confine your expectations to the feel of the original and leave yourself open to a plot that going in a truly interesting direction, you are in for a strong story.
reviews.review_header: If you liked Justice League: Gods and Monsters you'll like this too.

reviews.review_text: The APR starts at 16.99% and goes as high as 29.99%. This might be good for a small business starting out, but the terms are too high for me.
Approved but what a small credit limit considering I get 5K on a average, I Just got 500.00? A little disappointing If i have to pay an annual fee.
reviews.review_header: Approved but with a small credit limit 500.00 - My average credit limit is 6k. Disappointed

Plus the card is pretty spiffy or so I think!

reviews.review_text: less than 3 minutes... Fantastic way to apply from mobile device. Thank you amazon !!!

I love this card as a backup card. I am very pleased with the customer service department. I got my card fast and it was confirmed fast. As with any credit card, just watch you spending habits. Amazon is always taking things to the next level!
